field_edited_text.value:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways



Expressways in Relation to the Central Business District'

A residential suburb in Baltimore is not, by itself, very different from
a residential area in a smaller community. What distinguishes the Balti-
more suburb is the proximity of the downtown area and the corresponding
availability of all of the functions and services that customarily are located
there. It is in the center of our City that we find the large central
department stores, the small speciality shops, the theaters and amusement
centers, the hotels and restaurants, and the headquarters for much of our
cultural life. Here also is the center of the area’s economic activity, the
large offices, the important financial institutions, and the major concen-
tration of professional activities.

It is, of course, well known that our central business district has been
declining in importance as the rest of the metropolitan area grows. The
evidences of this decline have been too well established to warrant repeti-
tion here. It is pertinent to point out, however, that a continued decline
will represent something more than just a transfer of downtown functions
to more outlying areas. If the process continues some activities which
can only be supported on an area-wide basis will be wholly lost. A large
department store can establish suburban branches and perhaps end by
closing entirely its central store, as did Wanamakers in New York. Inade-
quate support for our one legitimate theater, however, cannot be remedied
by setting up a branch Ford’s in Towson and another in Glen Burnie.

Do we want a dispersed metropolitan area with some of our present
downtown functions abandoned and others distributed over a large area
so that we end up with a kind of homogenized city? Or do we want a
metropolitan area with a strong focal point and a vigorous, active center?
The business leadership of the community and the City Administration
have already decided in favor of a strong city center and the one-sided
vote in favor of Charles Center is ample evidence that this decision has
the support of the citizens.

30

The link between a strong central business district and the express-

way program is the question of accessibility. For Baltimore, as for any
other large city, the dominant characteristic of the central business dis-
trict is that it occupies the location having maximum accessibility from all
parts of the metropolitan area. Accessibility is, however, a relative matter.
If, as the metropolitan area grows, congestion increases so that it is more
difficult to reach the central business district, but if, at the same time,
congestion slows down other movements within the area to an equivalent
degree, the central business district will retain its relative accessibility
and its essential strength. On the other hand, if there are major highway
improvements in the outer sections of the area not matched by improve-
ments leading to the center of the city, the relative accessibility of the
central business district will be reduced and the central business district
will decline.

This point can be illustrated by some schematic examples. Assume
that the circle in Figure 2(a) represents a metropolitan area 10 miles in
radius with a normal pattern of surface streets. Assume also that
vehicular travel within one mile of the center averages 10 miles per hour
but that elsewhere it can proceed at 20 miles per hour. Let us also assume
that the point marked A is 8 miles due north of the center of the area
and that the point marked B is 8 miles due south. Based on these assump-
tions it can be demonstrated that all of the area shaded in the upper part
of the circle is more accessible to A than to the center. In other words,
a trip to any point in the shaded area can be done in shorter time starting
from A than starting from the center. The shaded portion represents 30%
of the metropolitan area. The balance, 70%, is more accessible to the



1The commonly accepted definition of the Central Business District has the
following approximate boundaries: Pratt Street on the south, Greene Street on the
west, Centre Street on the north, and the Fallsway on the east. The Central Business
District as thus defined is shown on Sheets 2 through 7.
